snippet: Mark Thompson, now president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, testified that he had never “knowingly misled” Parliament over the project’s progress.
abstract: Mark Thompson, former director general of the BBC, offers a general apology to a British parliamentary committee for the failure of the BBC's Digital Media Initiative, but insists that he had never knowingly misled Parliament or the BBC Trust; Thompson, now president and chief executive of The New York Time Company, testifies with other former BBC officials before the House of Commons Public Accounts Committee.

byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

lead_paragraph: Mark Thompson, now president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, testified that he had never “knowingly misled” Parliament over the project’s progress.

headline.main: Former BBC Director Apologizes for Failure of Digital Project
